profileText: A Representative from Maryland; born in Riverdale, Prince George's County, Md., August 24, 1808; completed preparatory studies at Bladensburg Academy, Md.; was graduated from the University of Virginia at Charlottesville in 1827; engaged in agricultural pursuits and stock breeding; member of the State house of delegates in 1839, 1843, and 1844; president of the Prince George's County Agricultural Society and the Maryland State Agricultural Society; vice president of the United States Agricultural Society; founded the first agricultural research college in America (later the Maryland Agricultural College at College Park), chartered in 1856; one of the early advocates for the establishment of the United States Department of Agriculture; elected as a Unionist to the Thirty-seventh Congress (March 4, 1861-March 3, 1863); was not a candidate for renomination in 1862; resumed agricultural pursuits; died in Riverdale, Prince George's County, Md., May 12, 1864; interment in Calvert Cemetery.

researchRecord.description: Letter to J.C. Nicholson from Charles Benedict Calvert written on September 29, 1858. In the letter, Charles Calvert describes his early plans for the Maryland Agricultural College, as the university was originally known. Writing from his home at Riversdale, Calvert tells Jacob Nicholson, a prominent printer in Baltimore, that "We expect to teach everything that is taught in the best Universities" and outlines specific courses to be included in the curriculum. He mentions laying the cornerstone for one of the two major buildings erected for the opening of the college and the plan to require students to engage "at certain hours in all the outdoor operations of the farm and work shops." Calvert's active role as the founder of the Maryland Agricultural College is clear from his concluding sentence to Nicholson, as he urges him to send his son to the new institution when it opens and asks for Nicholson's financial support for the fledgling college.
